content.description: Starting at the base of Battle of the Bulge, climb the arete just to ones left, formed by the Chatsworth Chimney.  The .11d crux can be bypassed by traversing out left then up (10d R).  This short pitch can be followed by Over and Out 5.9 R to gain the top of the rock
content.location: Base of Smooth Sole Rock, the obvious Chatsworth Chimney area.

content.description: Climb a long way up easy terrain to reach the first bolt (5.6R).  Getting established on the dark grey xenolith past the first bolt is the crux (11C or D).  5.11 climbing continues until the last bolt, then runout 5.10 climbing to the top.
content.location: This climb is located between Last Dance and Blown Out.  Start near the manzanita tree and wander up the expansive slab.  The first bolt of this route is located slightly higher than the second bolt of Blown Out, and about 20ft to its left.

climbs.name: Over and Out
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Troy Mayr, Mike Van Volkom

content.description: The crux is where the only bolts are located from the start of the pillar / route up the first bit.  The climbing gets easier the higher you go.
content.protection: 2 draws, perhaps a couple slings for possible chickenheads.  Solid two bolt anchor at top.  Can walkoff to the right down the descent gully to Sunshine Wall.
content.location:
Farthest right route on the left Smooth Soles Wall.  It climbs the arete above Chatsworth Chimney.  If leading: start from the bottom of the left Smooth Soles Wall and climb a large crack / pillar (easy) to the highest point.  From here the arete and bolts are very obvious.  If toproping: walk up the descent gully behind Smooth Soles Wall till you reach the two bolt anchor.  If you see only two bolts and no other set about 10' down, you are above the right side and need to traverse 20-40' further.

The Vogel / Gaines guidebook mentions a two bolt optional belay where the climb starts at the top of the pillar.  I only found one bolt that spins a bit.

content.description: This climb follows a very thin crack on the far left side of the wall.  It would be difficult to place gear in the upper part of the crack.  However, it's a fun route, and you can toprope it.  There are some thin lieback moves on the upper section.
content.protection: many thin pieces to 1/2", 2 bolt anchor

climbs.name: Drowned Out
climbs.fa: J. Knutson and Phil Warrender, September 1972

content.description: This is a one pitch face climb that gets sun all day.  The crux is at the third bolt.  It can be done by a long lunge (hard to assign a rating), or by a static 5.10 move.  A long runout on 5.6 knobs leads to the top.
content.protection: bolts and a few nuts and slings

climbs.name: Down and Out
climbs.fa: Gib Lewis and Jim Wilson, March 1974

content.description: This is a sustained, one pitch thin face route on great rock.  It is well protected, except for a runout above the first bolt, with a potential fall onto a pillar.  It is in the sun all day.

climbs.name: Blown Out
climbs.fa: Greg Bender and Phil Warrender, June 1972

content.description: This is a good, one pitch face route.  It is well protected except for a runout on moderate ground below the first bolt.  It's in the sun all day.
